properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Several hours of freezing rain expected on Sunday. Precipitation is expected to move into the area Sunday morning. The precipitation will begin as freezing rain and change to freezing drizzle or drizzle Sunday afternoon. Several millimeters of ice accretion are possible over these regions with some areas possibly receiving up to 5 cm of snow and ice pellets in addition to the freezing rain. Strong wind gusts up to 70 km/h coupled with ice accretion on tree branches and power lines could cause power outages. This wintry weather is associated with a Colorado Low that will track over Southern Ontario on Sunday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T12:25:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-30T20:26:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3182980160.2019

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain expected late tonight into Sunday. A strengthening low pressure system is expected to bring a messy mix of weather to the area beginning late tonight or early Sunday morning. Some areas could see several hours of freezing rain or ice pellets before transitioning to light rain or freezing drizzle late Sunday morning or Sunday afternoon. Strong wind gusts up to 70 km/h are also possible. Travel on roads could become hazardous at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T07:48:34-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing drizzle is weakening over southwestern Manitoba. This freezing drizzle should end for almost all areas this afternoon as drier air flows into the region. All freezing drizzle is expected to come to an end by Saturday evening. Remember that slippery conditions can persist on roads and walkways well after the freezing drizzle ends. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T01:59:40-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix expected Sunday. A strengthening low pressure system is expected to bring a messy mix of weather to the area beginning early Sunday morning. Some areas could see several hours of freezing rain or ice pellets before transitioning to light snow or freezing drizzle Sunday afternoon. Light snow is then expected to continue through Sunday night before tapering off Monday morning. Strong wind gusts up to 70 km/h and local blowing snow reducing visibilities are also possible. There remains some uncertainty as to the track of the low; however, there is the potential that some areas could see total snowfall or ice pellet amounts of 5 to 10 cm by Monday morning. Travel on roads could become hazardous at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T07:49:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-30T15:50:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1156017809.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected. Wave heights: 3 to 7 metres. Locations: North facing shorelines of The Gulf of St. Lawrence, Northumberland Strait and Cabot Strait. Time span: Tonight then subsiding on Sunday. Remarks: The highest waves will be at north facing shorelines of the Magdalen Islands, Prince Edward Island and Cape Breton where waves of 5 to 7 metres and water levels of near a metre above normal are expected. Over north facing shorelines of New Brunswick and mainland Nova Scotia, wave heights are expected to be in the 3 to 4 metre range with a water level of 50 cm to 1 metre above normal. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T12:35:28-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Sunday. Significant snowfall is expected in the region beginning Sunday morning and continuing through the night before tapering off Monday morning. The snow is expected to be mixed at times with ice pellets Sunday morning. The bulk of the precipitation is expected to fall throughout the day on Sunday. Total snowfall amounts of 20 cm are expected by Monday morning. Strong wind gusts up to 70 km/h and local blowing snow reducing visibilities are also expected throughout the day on Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Several hours of freezing rain expected on Sunday Precipitation is expected to move into the area early Sunday morning. The precipitation will begin as freezing rain then transition to ice pellets mixed with snow and patchy freezing rain early Sunday afternoon. The precipitation should taper off to drizzle or freezing drizzle by Sunday evening with flurries expected in the overnight hours. Several millimeters of ice accretion are possible over these regions with some areas possibly receiving 5 to 10 cm of snow and ice pellets in addition to the freezing rain. Strong wind gusts up to 70 km/h coupled with ice accretion on tree branches and power lines could cause power outages. This wintry weather is associated with a Colorado Low that will track over Southern Ontario on Sunday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T12:23:59-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Several hours of freezing rain expected on Sunday. Precipitation is expected to move into the area late tonight or early Sunday morning. The precipitation will begin as freezing rain and change to freezing drizzle or drizzle early Sunday afternoon. For areas closer to the lake shore the transition from freezing rain to drizzle will occur late Sunday morning. Several millimeters of ice accretion are possible over these regions with some areas possibly receiving a few centimeters of snow and ice pellets in addition to the freezing rain. Strong wind gusts up to 70 km/h coupled with ice accretion on tree branches and power lines could cause power outages. This wintry weather is associated with a Colorado Low that will track over Southern Ontario on Sunday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T12:27:00-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries at times heavy are expected. Snow squalls will continue as a cold northerly winds continue over the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Total snowfall: locally up to 10 cm overnight. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia and western Prince Edward Island. Time span: This this evening and overnight. Remarks: Flurries with periods of snow, heavy at times, will persist tonight. Snow squalls with locally poor visibility are likely. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T04:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-30T20:40:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3151011059.2019

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Sunday. This Winter Weather Travel Advisory has been upgraded from a Special Weather Statement that was previously in effect. A strengthening low pressure system is expected to bring a wintry mix of weather to the area beginning Sunday morning. Some areas could see several hours of freezing rain or ice pellets before transitioning to snow or freezing drizzle Sunday afternoon. Light snow is then expected to continue through Sunday night before tapering off Monday morning. Strong wind gusts up to 70 km/h and local blowing snow reducing visibilities are also possible. There remains some uncertainty as to the track of the low; however, there is the potential that some areas could see total snowfall or ice pellet amounts of 5 to 10 cm by Monday morning. Travel on roads could become hazardous at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Dominion City
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-12-01T09:15:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-30T09:15:58-06:00, 6A35DEB5-52A4-9914-2807-E009742D1F35
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant high-elevation snowfall will continue. Additional snowfall: 10 cm over the Long Range Mountains. Less than 5 cm along the coast. Locations: western Newfoundland. Anyone planning travel across higher parts of the Trans Canada Highway and Viking Trail should expect winter driving conditions. Users of backcountry trails should be prepared for large amounts of snowfall. Conditions may deteriorate suddenly over short distances. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility locally near zero in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring. Locations: Natuashish to Hopedale. Time span: tonight. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly up to 80 km/h in the Natuashish area and up to 110 km/h in the Hopedale area. Remarks: The main area of snow and blowing snow is expected to remain south of Nain. Conditions will significantly improve over all areas tonight. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: northerly up to 110 km/h. Location: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay. Time span: overnight tonight and Sunday morning. Remarks: The strongest winds are expected along the coast. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Sunday. A strengthening low pressure system is expected to bring significant snowfall to the region beginning late Sunday morning or Sunday afternoon and continuing through the night before tapering off Monday morning. The bulk of the precipitation is expected to fall throughout the afternoon and evening on Sunday. Strong wind gusts up to 60 km/h and local blowing snow reducing visibilities are also possible. There remains some uncertainty as to the track of the low; however, there is the potential that some areas could see total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm by Monday morning. Travel on roads could become hazardous at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T12:35:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-30T20:36:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3978419081.2019

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls with total amounts of 20 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia, Cape Breton Highlands and eastern Prince Edward Island. Time span: Tonight through to early Sunday morning. Remarks: A cold northerly flow and strong winds will continue to give flurries and snow squalls tonight and into Sunday morning and accumulations will vary with the intensity of the snow squalls with the highest amounts expected over the Cape Breton Highlands. An additional 10 cm of snow is possible overnight tonight in squalls. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T08:59:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-30T20:42:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3671119064.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Sunday. A strengthening low pressure system is expected to bring significant snowfall to the region beginning Sunday morning and continuing through the day before tapering off Sunday evening. There remains some uncertainty as to the track of the low; however, there is the potential that some areas could see total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm by Sunday night. Strong wind gusts up to 60 km/h could produce local blowing snow reducing visibilities. Travel on roads could become hazardous at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Strong localized winds are expected to develop in wind-prone areas this evening, and cause blowing snow. The winds and blowing snow are expected to strengthen and become more widespread Sunday afternoon. The blowing snow is expected to end on Monday afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-01T14:33:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-30T22:34:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3698318500.2019
